S4.T1.caption: Table 1: Performance comparison between the FedAvg and DifFense against pixel-pattern attacks on Fashion-MNIST after 150 global epochs and CIFAR10 after 300 global epochs.
S4.T1.table:
F-MNIST CIFAR10
FedAvg DifFense FedAvg DifFense
Final GA (%percent\%) 82.1 84.3 89.62 88.87
Mean BA (%percent\%) 6.15 0.68 7.71 0.25
references:
We compare the performance between FedAvg (baseline) and DifFense under pixel-pattern attack in Table 1 and semantic attack in Table 3, given one adversary. We can observe that DifFense’s global model accuracy is comparable to FedAvg’s.
Regardless of the trigger pattern, DifFense is more robust to attacks with the average backdoor accuracy of below 2%percent22\%.
DifFense’s strong FL performance is attributed to its low false positive rate of below 7%percent77\% and zero false negative rate as shown in Table 2, 4.

We compare the performance between FedAvg (baseline) and DifFense under pixel-pattern attack in Table 1 and semantic attack in Table 3, given one adversary. We can observe that DifFense’s global model accuracy is comparable to FedAvg’s.
Regardless of the trigger pattern, DifFense is more robust to attacks with the average backdoor accuracy of below 2%percent22\%.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3: Performance comparison between FedAvg, Multi-Krum (denoted as Krum), CooMedian and DifFense against semantic attack on CIFAR10 dataset with a different number of adversaries.
S4.T3.table:
Number of adversaries 1 2 3
Aggregation method FedAvg Krum CooMed DifFense FedAvg Krum CooMed DifFense FedAvg Krum CooMed DifFense
Final GA 89.06 90.04 85.91 89.41 89.7 89.87 88.82 84.1 89.18 87.94 88.89 89.77
Max BA 100 34.8 45.9 10.5 99.9 96.8 94.5 11.9 100 98.8 96.8 15.5
Mean BA 14.85 2.84 4.4 0.41 17.86 2.07 9.69 1.15 24.8 3.6 4.29 1.94
references:
We compare the performance between FedAvg (baseline) and DifFense under pixel-pattern attack in Table 1 and semantic attack in Table 3, given one adversary. We can observe that DifFense’s global model accuracy is comparable to FedAvg’s.
Regardless of the trigger pattern, DifFense is more robust to attacks with the average backdoor accuracy of below 2%percent22\%.
DifFense’s strong FL performance is attributed to its low false positive rate of below 7%percent77\% and zero false negative rate as shown in Table 2, 4.

We can observe in Table 3, 4 that DifFense obtains a lower average backdoor accuracy than other methods with consistently zero false negative rate while achieving a global accuracy comparable to the baseline with below 7%percent77\% of false positive rate. Compared to Multi-Krum, DifFense successfully detects all the adversaries while yielding a lower false positive rate, regardless of the number of adversaries.

We also compute the maximum backdoor accuracy of each method after the global model reaches the test accuracy of 85%percent8585\% in Table 3.
DifFense’ backdoor accuracy is consistently lower than 16%percent1616\% while other methods’ reach 95%percent9595\% with multiple adversaries. To sum up, DifFense steadily presents a stronger performance than FedAvg, Multi-Krum and CooMed given a various number of adversaries.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5: Performance analysis of DifFense with respect to the number of differential images generated with 300 epochs of global training on CIFAR10 dataset under semantic attack.

# Differential Inputs 20 50 100
Final GA 89.41 89.93 89.15
Mean BA 0.41 2.49 3.14

references: We run a sensitivity analysis to investigate whether DifFense’s effectiveness is correlated with the number of generated differential images. We can observe that the final global accuracy is consistently around

and the average false negative rate is zero.
Fixing the number of differential images as
, we differentiate the number of distinct classes that the images belong to. We assume that differential images are

distributed across the given classes. We can observe that the average false positive rate decreases as more classes are used while false negative rate is flat zero. However, even with one class, DifFense achieves a false positive rate of below

and the final global accuracy comparable to the one whose differential images are from all the classes. This alleviates the burden of securing validation images distributed across a number of classes. Also, using images from only few classes can reduce the runtime as the computational complexity of Algorithm
is affected by the number of image classes.

We corroborate the effectiveness of two-step MAD outlier detection compared to the original single and double MAD variants.

). Two-step MAD outlier detection achieves the zero false negative rate while suppressing the false positive rate to below
